text: I want to talk about treatment of
hypertension here's a problem with
hypertension hypertension is often
undiagnosed because of the fact that the
symptoms are very vague things like
fatigue and lightheadedness and
headaches and those types of things are
what you usually have and it's not
really giving you any significant
symptoms until you have serious problems
now when it comes to treatment there are
a number of things that can be done and
of course the first thing that we can
look at is some lifestyle modifications
and how that affects general
cardiovascular help so we're dealing
with things like stopping smoking so
stop smoking weight reduction so weight
loss weight loss I don't like this color
let's go back to white aerobic exercise
aerobic exercise regularly aerobic I'm
just gonna put X and caffeine intake so
reducing reduction and coffee let's just
say coffee intake sodium intake so salt
and just generally eating well so let's
say eating fruits and veggies of course
it's not just fruits and veggies but
that's a good staple in terms of
thinking about health so some of these
general things that we can do are gonna
help with preventing or help with
hypertension help with reversing the
effects of hypertension now of course in
some cases it's gonna be a little more
advanced than these lifestyle
modifications yes you want to make them
but in some cases you're gonna need some
extra help and we're gonna talk about
some of the drugs that can be taken to
really help with hypertension so let's
take some examples now we spoke about
this in a previous video where we showed
that
blood pressure is equal to cardiac
output times peripheral resistance and
if you increase any of these you're
gonna increase the blood pressure now on
the flip side if one of these are
increased and that's causing an increase
in blood pressure what you want to do is
reduce one or both of these values so
that that can reduce the blood pressure
and stop it from getting any worse and
there are a number of ways to do this
using pharmacological agents first I
want to talk about those that are gonna
decrease peripheral resistance or at
least stop that from increasing the
first one will be what we call ACE
inhibitors and as you can imagine that's
gonna inhibit this enzyme here basically
essentially knocking that out so that
we're not getting the conversion of
angiotensin 1 to angiotensin 2 which is
such a potent vasoconstrictor that is
gonna increase peripheral resistance
significantly so we're stopping this
process from happening so that
peripheral resistance can be decreased
or at least not increased
any more that is the result of using the
class of drugs that we call is
inhibitors there's another class of
drugs that's gonna also work against
this increase in peripheral resistance
and those are drugs that are gonna block
so let's just say a block sympathetic
stimulation if you're blocking
sympathetic stimulation sympathetic
stimulation normally causes
vasoconstriction so you're gonna stop
this right here so that you are reducing
them on a vasoconstriction and in
essence you're decreasing peripheral
resistance so those are two different
types of drugs that are gonna work to
reduce peripheral resistance and if we
reduce peripheral resistance we reduce
blood pressure and we're helping to stop
this cycle from continuing so those are
drugs that are gonna affect peripheral
resistance let's talk about
drugs that are going to affect cardiac
output number one those are gonna be
your diuretics diuretics what is that
going to cause a diuretic is causing an
increase in urination and if you cause
an increase in urination what you're
basically doing is counteracting this
process where we're gonna have an
increase in water reabsorption instead
of having an increase in water
re-absorption we're gonna have an
increase in water secretion so water
won't be going back into the bloodstream
along with sodium it's going to be
leaving so we're gonna cause sodium ions
to leave and as a result of that water
is also leaving those are your diuretics
and of course if that is happening that
is gonna cause a reduction in blood
volume and as a result of that a
reduction in cardiac output and a
reduction in blood pressure so we're
stopping the process in terms of
decreasing the cardiac output another
way of affecting cardiac output more
directly is with a class of drugs that
are called beta blockers beta blockers
are gonna block the beta receptors on
the heart and those are responsible for
responding to sympathetic stimulation
sympathetic stimulation that's
fight-or-flight it's speeding things up
it's causing increased contraction of
the heart and if we're blocking those
beta receptors we are basically gonna be
decreasing the cardiac output because
the heart will not contract as strongly
and as a result of that we're decreasing
the cardiac output decreasing the blood
pressure so we're stopping the process
right here or counteracting the process
right here so those are some of the
drugs that are used some of the main
types of drugs we have our ACE
inhibitors and we can we have drugs that
block sympathetic stimulation basically
in essence either knocking out that or
reducing the effect of that angiotensin
converting enzyme
and reducing the amount of
vasoconstriction and then we have those
that are going to affect cardiac output
either by causing more water excretion
or the beta blockers that are gonna
reduce the amount of the strength of
contraction of the heart so there you
have it that's it for this video and
I'll see you in the next one
